message: It's like the fantastic AnyJSON module, but has its own fallback. Enjoy!
I just released a new module called omnijson: http://pypi.python.org/pypi/omnijson
It looks cool, but it doesn't quite work for me:

$ python
Python 2.7.1+ (r271:86832, Jan  1 2011, 12:29:50)
[GCC 4.4.3] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import omnijson as json
>>> json.loads('{"channel":"24e67e0d-1cad-4cc0-9e7a-f8523ef460fe","depth":{"price":17.69991,"type":1,"volume":1},"op":"private","origin":"broadcast","private":"depth"}')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/omnijson/core.py", line 39, in loads
    return _engine[0](s, **kwargs)
NameError: global name 'kwargs' is not defined
>>> ^D
$
All JSON modules from ujson to simplejson/json are installed, and are the newest versions available from the cheese shop.
http://pypi.python.org/pypi/omnijson "Features: Verndorizable" -- typo for "vendorizable"? what does that mean?
It means you can package OmniJSON with your own module/application so a user doesn't need to install OmniJSON if your module/application requires it.
I have similar logic in amara, and I'm considering testing this vendorizability (erk, what a pukish term ;) ). One question: what's the tox.ini thingy?
To clarify the above, I'm considering scrapping amara's logic and just bundling omnijson
